docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This is where I'll house my long term goals for learning Japanese.

docs.title: Goals
docs.text:
• Take and Pass the JLPT N3
  • Play Persona 5 Royal in Japanese with Japanese Subtitles by my 29th birthday
  • Watch Parasyte: The Maxim in japanese with Japanese subtitles by my 29th birthday

docs.title: October 2023 Goals
docs.text:
• Finish Japanese From Zero book 2: Finished 10/06/2023
  • Learn 300 vocabulary words 10 per day (will bring me to 569 vocabulary words learned)
  • Immerse with two episodes of Laid Back Camp (Yuru Camp)

docs.title: November 2023 Goals
docs.text:
• Review grammar on bunpro everyday
  • Do at least 5 cram study sessions on currently known grammar on bunpro
  • Study 10 new vocab every day

docs.title: Stretch Goal
docs.text: • Finish Japanese From Zero book 3 (might not get to until December as I want to focus mostly on grammar review this month)

docs.title: Under an amount
docs.text:
[amount] + い下

Example

百人い下　→　100 people or less

docs.title: Turning adjectives into attributes
docs.text:
Attributes can be made out of most of the い-adjectives by dropping the い and adding さ

Once you have created the attribute, you can use it just as you would use any noun in a sentence to say things like, The length is two feet.

Examples:

docs.title: せんせん (not) at all
docs.text: ぜんぜん means not at all but can be used as the slang for totally; completely, exceptionally

docs.title: Meaning
docs.text: それに can mean and in addition or and is also depending on the context.

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
それに is used to connect two sentences. It is placed at the beginning of the second sentence.

Examples

  • 渡辺さんは優しい。それに、おもしろいです　→　Mr./Ms. Watanabe is kind. And also, he/she is interesting.
  • 日本は人がおおいです。それに、来るまもおおいです　→　Japan has many people. And in addition there are many cars too.

docs.title: だいたい
docs.text: 大体 is an adverb that is used to highlight the main point of something in Japanese. 大体 will regularly be translated as 'mostly', 'generally', or 'for the most part'

docs.title: とおもう (to think)
docs.text:
In sentences using おもう, the phrase that makes up the thought must be in informal form. Even です should be conjugated to だ.

Examples:

docs.title: Adjectives
docs.text:
In sentences where an adjective exists, です is removed from the sentence.

Example

これはおいしいとおもいます　→　I think this tates good.

docs.title: Difference between はじまる and はじめる
docs.text:
The verb はじまる (to begin, start) and はじめる (to initiate, start, begin) are very similar, but they should not be mixed up.

はじまる is used when stating that an event starts or beings passively

はじまる Example

  • 学校がはじまる　→　School will start.

はじめる is used when stating that something is originated or was initiated actively. That is, the event is not starting automatically, someone is phyiscally starting the event.

はじめる Example

  • 学校をはじめる　→　(Someone) will start a school.

docs.title: より
docs.text: より, when used alone means more than, instead of, than, or rather than

docs.title: Over an amount
docs.text:
[amount] + い上

Examples

千ドルい上　→　1000 dollars or greater
百人い上　→　100 people or more

docs.title: う-Verb (Negative-Past)
docs.text:
The あ form + ない is used to make the present / future negative form for regular verbs.

Examples

  • すわる　→　すわらない
  • うたう　→　うたわない
  • あるく　→　あるかない
  • はなす　→　はなさない
  • うつ　→　うたない
  • しぬ　→　しなない
  • とぶ　→　とばない
  • やすむ　→　やすまない
  • およぐ　→　およがない

docs.title: Exceptions:
docs.text: • ある　→　ない

docs.title: る-Verb (Negative-Past)
docs.text:
In order to form the negative past form of る-Verbs, you will need to remove the る, and then follow it with the auxiliary verb ない (or ます), conjugated into their past forms. This will either be なかった.

Examples

  • 食べる　→　食べなかった
  • 見る　→　見なかった
  • ねる　→　ねなかった

docs.title: Between
docs.text:
あいだ meaning 'between' must be structured in the following way:

  • The dog is between ITEM 1 and ITEM 2

Example

  • いぬはITEM1とITEM2のあいだにます → The dog is between item 1 and item 2

docs.title: あんまり
docs.text:
Previously, I learned that あんまり means 'not that much.'. It also means 'not that often' and is used with negative verbs. You can almost think of あんまり as the opposite of よく

Examples

  • あんまり東京に行きます → I don't go to Tokyo often.
  • あんまりバナナを食べます → I don't eat bananas often.

docs.title: い Adjectives
docs.text:
い adjectives all have one thing in common: they all end in い

Important

  • い adjectives will always have the い outside of the kanji. If the い is inside the kanji, it is not an い adjective.
  • い adjectives must never be followed by だ. This is due to だ only being able to conjugate with nouns (which な-Adjectives originally are)

docs.title: Modifying い Adjectives
docs.text:
To modify a word, they are simply placed in front of it

Examples

  • たかいｋるま　→　an expensive car
  • おもしろいテレビ　→　an interesting TV
  • あかいりんご　→　a red apple
  • ちいさい猫　→　a small cat
  • おいしいピザ　→　delicious pizza

docs.title: い Adjectives Polite Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the polite form by simply adding です to the end.

Examples

  • あついです　→　hot
  • きょうは、あついです　→　It's hot today.

docs.title: い Adjectives Causal Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the casual form by simply removing the です at the end.

Examples

  • あつい　→　hot
  • きょうは、あつい　→　It's hot today.

docs.title: Making い Adjectives Past Tense
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into past tense by taking the い off the end and adding かった. This works for the negative and positive forms of the adjective

Examples

あたらしい　→　new
あたらしかった　→　was new

あたらしくない　→　not new
あたらしくなかった　→　was not new

docs.title: い Adjectives Negative Form
docs.text:
い adjectives can be made into the negative form by taking the い off the end and adding くない

Examples

  • あつくないです　→　not hot
  • きょうは、あつくないです　→　It's not hot today.

docs.title: Things To Know
docs.text:
1. Sentence 1 is always the REASON and sentence 2 is the RESULT
  2. Sentence 1 is better sounding as casual form. The politeness of the sentece is determined by sentence 2.

Example 1:

Example 2:

docs.title: Which verb form to use with から sentences
docs.text:
It sounds more natural for the verb in sentence 1 to be informal. The formality of the entire sentence is decided by the verb in sentence 2

However, you can use different forms. Here is a list of the combinations allowed when creating から statements:

Important

You can never have a formal verb in sentence 1 and then an informal verb in sentence 2

There is an easy way to remeber the patterns that are allowed. You can go across the politeness (informal → informal) or (polite → polite). You can also go up in politeness (informal → polite). But you can never go down (polite → informal). Never go down. That is the shortcut.

Example Sentences

In English, we switch between "so", "since", or "because" depending on how you want the sentence to sound. However, the Japanese sentence remains the same regardless of which one is used.

  • 友達がいないから、さびしいです　→　I am lonely because I don't have any friends.
  • 明日東京に行くから、今日スーツケースをかいます　→　I am going to Tokyo tomorrow, so I will buy a suitcase

docs.title: What happens with です?
docs.text:
What happens with です depends on what is directly before the です. If sentence 1 ends with an い adjective (any tense), the です is removed.

Example:

If sentence 1 ends with a な adjective or a noun then です changes to the informal form of です, which is だ

Examples:

docs.title: Making things polite with ください
docs.text: By adding ください after the て forms, you make things sound nice by adding please. The same particle and sentence structure rules of other verb forms are applied when using the て form.

docs.title: Making specific amounts less specific with ぐらい
docs.text:
くらい or ぐらい (more common in spoken Japanese) means 'about'; however, it is used with amounts and time durations. It can be used to make any exact amount less specific.

Examples:

docs.title: Making specific times less specific with ごろ
docs.text:
ごろ, which means 'around' or 'about', is used to make specific times less specific. It always comes after the time.

Examples:

docs.title: そして
docs.text: そして means "and" and is used to connect two sentences. と, which also means "and", is only used to connect items in a list and cannot be used to connect sentences

docs.title: The た Form
docs.text:
The informal past tense form (calling it the た form), is made by converting the final hiragana of the dictionary form into various combindations

Examples:

docs.title: I want to...
docs.text:
To make the "want to" form of a verb, たい is added to the い form of the verb. For regular verbs, the following pattern is used:

Examples

docs.title: Changing verbs with the て form
docs.text: Conjugating verbs into the て form is based on the ending hiragana of the dictionary form of the verb. The て form formula is only used for regular verbs, since for いる/える verbs, you simply switch the last る to a て.

docs.title: Changing verbs into the positive て form (the "do it" form)
docs.text: Most of the time, verbs ending in く change to いて. For example, 書く (to write) changes to 書いて. One of the exceptions is 行く (to go), which changes to 行って.

docs.title: Changing verbs into the negative て form (the "don't do it" form)
docs.text: This is the pattern to use when making the "don't do it form":

docs.title: Regular Verb Examples
docs.text: Regular Verb Examples

docs.title: いる/える Verb Examples
docs.text: いる/える Verb Examples

docs.title: Irregular Verbs
docs.text: The irregular verbs する and くる do not follow any pattern that you know to conjugate them into the て form.

docs.title: Verbs that end in う
docs.text:
When the dictionary form actually ends with an う, the う changes to a わ and then ないで is added to it when creating the negative て form.

Verbs ending in う examples

docs.title: The ています verb form
docs.text:
The ています form is the verb + -ing form in English. It is used when an action is currently taking place or is ongoing. The ています form of a verb is made by adding います after the positive て-form of the verb.

Examples:

docs.title: ています vs. てます
docs.text: In spoken Japanese, people often drop the い sound in the ています verb form. Typically this shouldn't be done when writing, but when speaking it sounds more relaxed and casual.

docs.title: State of being
docs.text:
The ている/ています form is also used to describe a "state of being". This is usually the result of an action, and you are left with whatever state you are in.

Examples:

docs.title: Meaning
docs.text:
でしょう is a conjugated form of です, and can also be seen in the contracted form でしょ (more casual).

でしょう is regularly translated to 'right?', or 'probably'. In a broader sense, it just expresses an assertion about something (like です), that the speaker assumes the listener would probably agree with.

Example

彼もおどるでしょう　→ He will probably dance too

docs.title: Modifying な Adjectives
docs.text:
な adjectives must have な after them when directly modifying. They cannot be used to modify unless な comes after them.

Examples

  • きらいなくるま　→　a clean car
  • べんりなみせ　→　a convenient store

docs.title: な Adjectives Polite Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the polite form by simply adding です to the end.

Examples

  • しずかです　→　quiet
  • きょうは、しずかです　→　It's quiet today.

docs.title: な Adjectives Causal Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the casual form by simply removing the です at the end and replacing it with だ

Example

  • しずかだ　→　It's quiet.

docs.title: Making な Adjectives Past Tense
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into past tense by adding でした at the end.

Example

  • しずかでした　→　It was quiet.

docs.title: な Adjectives Negative Form
docs.text:
な adjectives can be made into the negative form by adding ではありません

Examples

  • しずかではありません　→　not quiet
  • きょうは、しずかではありません　→　It's not quiet today.

docs.title: The ましょう verb ending
docs.text:
The ましょう verb ending is added to the verb root to say things like let's go, or let's eat. In question form, ましょう means Shall we~?

Examples

  • いきましょう → Let's go
  • 帰りましょう → Let's return
  • たべましょう → Let's eat

docs.title: まだ Meaning
docs.text: まだ means 'not yet' or 'still'.

docs.title: まだ Usage
docs.text: まだ can be used with positive or negative adjectives and verbs. Generally, but not always, whene まだ is used with negative words, it means 'yet'. When it is used with positive words, it means 'still'.

docs.title: もう
docs.text: The meaning of もう changes depending on usage.

docs.title: もう means 'already' when placed in front of the positive past tens verbs (た form):
docs.text:
Examples

  • もういきました → I already went there.
  • もう食べました -> I already ate it.
  • もうのみました -> I already drank it.
  • もう読みました -> I already read it.

docs.title: もう also means "already" in front of time related words:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もうなつです -> it's summer already.
  • もうさんじです -> It's already three o' clock.

docs.title: もう can also mean "more" when placed in front of number words:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もう一つ -> one more
  • もう三人 -> three more people

docs.title: もう means "anymore" when placed in front of negative verbs:
docs.text:
Examples

  • もういきません -> I don't want to go anymore.
  • もうたべません -> I'm not going to eat anymore.
  • もうのみまっせん -> I don't drink anymore.

docs.title: もう can also be used with other words with じゃない after them. In this case, もう means "anymore"
docs.text:
Examples

  • もうこどもじゃないです -> I'm not a child anymore.
  • もう私のともだちじゃないです -> They aren't my friends anymore.

docs.title: よく Meaning
docs.text:
よく means "often" and is placed in front of positive verbs.

Examples

  • よく東京に行きます → I often go to Tokyo.
  • よくバナナを食べますか → Do you often eat bananas?
  • 私はよく日本に帰ります → I often return to Japan.

docs.title: This is better than that
docs.text:
Depending on the context, より can mean "than, more, than or instead of"

Used to say one item is better, newer, older, bigger, more liked, etc. than another item.

docs.title: Stringing い adjectives in a row
docs.text:
In English, if we want to say "little, white car," we just simply string the adjectives in a row and it works. In Japanese, the adjectives must be changed into what we will call the くて form. The い is dropped and くて is added. Every adjective in the row must be in the くて form except for the very last one, which should be normal.

Examples:

docs.title: Plurals in Japanese with たち
docs.text: There are plurals that are made using たち after certain words. たち is normally used with people and is only used with non-living things when they're being given human characteristics like 星たちが母絵見ました (stars smiled). The most common plurals:

docs.title: たち after names
docs.text: When たち comes after a name, as in 田中さんたち, it means that 田中 is part of a group and he/she is being used to describe that group or is a representative of that group.

docs.title: The question word どう
docs.text:
どう means "how" or "what", depending on the context. It is also very commonly used when asking someone's opinion

Examples:

docs.title: Using なにも
docs.text:
なにも is always used with negative verbs or adjectives.

Examples:

docs.title: Using か for saying or
docs.text: か can be used between words in a list to say 'or'. It is optional to have か after the last item.

docs.title: で Particle
docs.text:
The particle で means with, by, or on. It marks the item that is being used to do something. It is also used to mark modes of transportation.

Examples:

docs.title: Uses
docs.text: The と particle can be used to say 'and' as well as 'with'

docs.title: And
docs.text:
The 'and' version of と is always used between two words.

Examples

  • いぬとねこ → dog and cat
  • 貴方と私 → you and I
  • りんごとすし → apples and sushi

docs.title: With
docs.text:
The 'with' version of と is always used after a word, never between.

Examples

  • 田中さんと → with Mr/Mrs. Tanaka
  • まりさんはまことさんと帰ります → Mari will return with Makoto.
  • 僕は小林さんと行きます → I am going with Mr. Kobayashi

docs.title: Thought-, Opinion-, Quotation-marker
docs.text:
This と is unrelated to the 'and' and 'with' meanings of と. We will call it the thought-, opinion-, quotation-marker, for lack of a better name. Anything that is thought or said is marked with と.

Important

The と must come after the thought

docs.title: The particle と with the verb いう (to say, tell)
docs.text:
When using 「something」 といいます, anything can be inside the quotation marks.

The sentence that is being quoted sounds more natural if the verb in it is changed to its informal version. For example, 行きます should be changed to 行く, and たべました should be changed to たべた

Examples:

docs.title: The particle と with the verb きく
docs.text:
When saying「something」と聞きました, all verbs in the quotations should be used in their informal versions.

Examples:

docs.title: When です ends the sentence being quoted or idea
docs.text:
When the sentence being quoted ends in です, will need to change it to the informal だ. Similiarly, if the sentence ends in でした, it should be changed to the informal だった

Examples:

docs.title: Event Frequency with に
docs.text:
What 'event frequency' means is how often or how many times an event occurs. The counter for frequency is 回.

You can use event frequency in a sentence with a time span to say how many times something has been done in a certain period of time.

Example Q & A

Q: 貴方は一年に何回アメリカに来ますか　→　How many times a year do you come to America?

A1: 一年に四回行きます　→　I go four times a year

A2: 二年に一回行きます　→　I go once every two years

docs.title: Noun Connector
docs.text:
の can be used to connect two nouns. A noun that has been changed into an adjectived using の is considered a の adjective. A noun cannot describe or modify another noun unless の comes after it.

Example

  • 大学の先生 → a college professor

docs.title: Possessive Connector
docs.text:
の can be used to indicate possession

Example

  • あれは私のぺんです → That over there is my pen.

docs.title: Of
docs.text: の can also mean of

docs.title: Question marker の
docs.text:
This の acts as the か question marker. It's placed after informal verb forms to make a question.

Note

The informal form is almost never used in written form. It's used in informal conversattions (with close friends, family). It should never be used when speaking to someone considered to be of higher social status than the speaker (boss, teacher, etc.).

Examples

  • 東京に行きの？　→　Will you go to Tokyo?
  • 日本にいったの？　→　Did you go to Japan?
  • いえに帰ったの？　→　Did you return home?

docs.title: Using の to create emphasis
docs.text:
When a sentence (not a question) ends in の, and without an updard intonation, it will tend to have more emotion or emphasis.

Important

It's NOT normal for men to use の unless it's a question. Men's response to an informal question with の would end with よ or with just the informal verb

Examples:

docs.title: よ Particle
docs.text:
When a sentence ends with よ it's like adding an exclamation mark. It can be used to convey strong feeling, emotion, and sometimes triumph. It can also be used for emphasis: I'm certain (of what has just been said).

Note

In casual conversation, when said in a neutral tone, よ doesn't add any emotion, however, よ can be assertive when used with a stronger tone.

Examples:

docs.title: を Particle
docs.text: を is a direct object marker. を must always come after an item which receives or is affected by the action of a verb. No matter where the object that is being eaten, bought, sold, etc., is located in the sentence, the object particle must come after it.

docs.title: Study Plan
docs.text: I wanted a place to formulate some thoughts on my intended path going forward for studying. This is likely to change as I get further in my learning journey, but this is will always be what my current study plan is at the moment.

docs.title: Plan as of 11/10/2023
docs.text:
I still plan on starting the Tango N4 vocabulary deck after I finish Tango N5. However, after I finish Tango N5, I plan on doing mostly card reviews for a week or so (maybe two). During this time, I will mostly focus on building N5 level grammar. I'm a decent way there, but there's still more I need to work on. The one - two weeks following the completion of Tango N5 will be when I get to a good point before moving on to more N4 level stuff.

After I finish Tango N4 which will take some time of course (probably like two months), I will do the same thing for N4 level grammar as I did with N5.

After completing both vocabulary decks and finishing my Japanese From Zero text books (N5 & N4 grammar), I'll begin immersion. I plan on primarily using anime and graded readers. I may also use graded podcasts but those will be less frequent.

Overall, I will continue using bunpro for srs grammar practice going forward as it's a great way to train the grammar muscle.

docs.title: Currently Using
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

Info

These resources are the online resources I've found or are using. This will not include any type of textbook or anki deck.

I'm also not including youtube playlists or channels as I have those stored in youtube already (accessible anywhere)

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text: • Bunpro: Pretty cool. Groups grammar points by N~ level or by textbook. Will essentially make the equivolent of an Anki deck in the UI. I use it more so for repetition but I learn from text books.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text: • Jisho: Tried and true lookup dictionary. Probably use it every day lol

docs.title: TV / Movies
docs.text:
• Aniwatch.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Aniwave.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text: • Yomichan: Yomichan is a browser extension that allows you to look up Japanese words with both the meaning and the reading on web pages with ease.

docs.title: Not Using Currently
docs.text:
Important

I add and remove items from here all the time. I'm finding new resources all the time so I will update this page monthly so it's not always correct.

Info

These resources are the online resources I've found or are using. This will not include any type of textbook or anki deck.

I'm also not including youtube playlists or channels as I have those stored in youtube already (accessible anywhere)

docs.title: Grammar
docs.text:
• TokiniAndy Course: He has free youtube videos but the course is amazing. Has graded readers, shadowing practice, vocabulary review, textbook lesson and practice (Genki), and more. I'm not using it anymore as I'm following a different book than genki now.

  • Genki Study Resources By Seth Clydesdale: Amazing resource if you're going through Genki 1. Has a ton of practice for all lessons of Genki 1

docs.title: Graded Readers
docs.text:
• Tadoku Graded Readers: Free graded books

  • Satori Reader: Graded reader (paid)

  • NHK Easy News: Essentially a graded reader but with Japanese news

docs.title: Browser Extensions
docs.text: • Asbplayer: Load local subtitle files to video streaming sites.

docs.title: Dictionaries
docs.text: • jpdb: Have pretty cool features. Also cool for generated Anki decks for anime, novels, etc. Essentially allowing you to skip sentence mining.

docs.title: TV / Movies
docs.text:
• Kitsunekko: Probably the biggest collection of Japanese subtitles for anime. An absolute lifesaver for immersion.

  • Super Native: Cool site that trains you to hear, read, and speak Japanese from TV and movies.

  • Language Reactor: Kind of like migaku or asbplayer in a way. Embeds directly to youtube or netflix (there are others). Allows you to mine from TV and movies.

  • Aniwatch.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Aniwave.to: Anime streaming site (mostly use for anime that isn't on any streaming platforms like Crunchyroll, Hidive, Amazon, etc.)

  • Animelon: Can actually stream anime with Japanese subtitles which is pretty cool. Don't use it a ton but.

docs.title: Manga
docs.text: • Mokuro: Allows you to read Japanese manga with Yomichan selectable text inside a browser.

docs.title: Games
docs.text: • Game2Text: Essentially adds the ability to parse Japanese from games

docs.title: Kanji
docs.text: • Kanji Map: Really cool resource for learning stroke patterns

docs.title: Podcasts
docs.text: • Japanese Podcast Spreadsheet: Has a huge list of podcasts in Japanese. There's also a list (starter pack), that's sorted by Japanese level.

docs.title: Sentence Search
docs.text:
• Immersion Kit: Made by game gengo (amazing youtuber!). You can search sentences from anime, games, etc. with translation.

  • Youglish: Sentences sourced from YouTube video subtitles. Great tool for pronunciation as the words are said by native speakers speaking naturally.

docs.title: Sentence Mining Setup
docs.text:
For right now, I'm using a prebuilt anki templating system.

Info

I plan on making my own template with a variation of a couple of different templates in the future. As I'm not really mining a whole lot right now as I'm still building foundational vocabulary knowledge, creating my own template isn't necessary at the moment.

docs.title: Guide
docs.text: • JP Mining Note

docs.title: Yomichan Setup
docs.text: When searching for ways to start mining sentences from anime, yomichan was the resource the I used the most.

docs.title: Guides
docs.text:
I followed two guides (one for yomichan itself as I think it's a bit clearer, and one for setting up yomichan for mining)

  • JP Mining Note: For mining
  • TheMoeWay: For general Yomichan setup (dictionaries, etc.)
